description: From grow +‎ -th. Compare Old Frisian grēd ("meadow, pasture"; > North Frisian greyde (“growth, pasture”)), Middle High German gruote, gruot (“greens, fresh growth, shoot”), Old Norse gróðr ("growth, crop"; > Faroese grøði, Danish grøde (“fruits”), Swedish gröda (“crop, harvest”)). More at grow.

entries.meaning: An increase in size, number, value, or strength.

examples: Growth was dampened by a softening of the global economy in 2001, but picked up in the subsequent years due to strong growth in China.

entries.meaning: An increase in psychological strength or resilience; an increased ability to overcome adversity.
examples: Struggle, disappointment, and criticism all contribute to a person's growth.

entries.meaning: (biology) The act of growing, getting bigger or higher.
(biology) Something that grows or has grown.
(pathology) An abnormal mass such as a tumor.
